hints.content: First, we need to find $9\dfrac12$ grams on the number line.

options.alt: A line plot that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 9, 9 and a half, and 10. The 9 and a half tick mark is marked with a vertical dotted line. !

hints.content:
Each dot represents one strawberry. 

So, we need to count all of the dots on the line plot that represent weights less than $9 \dfrac12$ grams.  

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled Strawberry weights (grams) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above 7, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 7 and 8, 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9, 3 dots above 9, 2 dots above 10, 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 11 and 12, and 2 dots above 12. The unlabeled tick mark between 9 and 10 is marked with a vertical dotted line. The dots to the left of the vertical dotted line (to the left of 9 and 1 half grams) are all highlighted. !

hints.content:
There are $\maroonD{10}$ dots that represent weights less than $9 \dfrac12$ grams.   

$\maroonD{10}$ strawberries weigh less than $9 \dfrac12$ grams.

question.content:
The weights of some strawberries are shown below.  

[[☃ image 1]]

**How many strawberries are less than $9 \dfrac12$ grams?** 
 
[[☃ input-number 1]] strawberries

options.alt: A line plot labeled Strawberry weights (grams) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above 7, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 7 and 8, 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9, 3 dots above 9, 2 dots above 10, 5 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 3 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 11 and 12, and 2 dots above 12. !
